feed.title: Combined summary - On consensus changes in bitcoin 2024

entry.title: Combined summary - On consensus changes in bitcoin 2024
entry.summary:
The discourse on Bitcoin development and governance explores the intricate dynamics between developers, miners, and the broader community in effecting protocol changes. It challenges the traditional view that miners are the primary decision-makers in this process by highlighting a more collaborative approach that requires developer consensus before proposals are presented to miners. This shift underscores the fragmented direction among developers as a substantial hurdle.
In addressing governance deadlocks, the conversation delineates between direct and representative democracy models within the Bitcoin ecosystem, scrutinizing their viability against Bitcoin's foundational principles. The dialogue identifies a leadership void formerly filled by "trusted figures," suggesting criteria for future leaders that resonate with Bitcoin's ethos and technical demands. Concerns over Bitcoin mining's environmental impact are raised, alongside the necessity for sustainable practices.
The discussion also ventures into the technical consensus challenges, exemplified by the OP_EVAL proposal, advocating for organic development and consensus outside formal Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs) to spur innovation while upholding review standards. It emphasizes adaptability in Bitcoin's development philosophy, cautioning against stagnation and underscoring the importance of evolving perspectives to maintain Bitcoin's relevance. The detrimental effects of personal attacks within the community on constructive debate and progress are highlighted.
A comprehensive examination of soft forks, consensus rules, and the historical "block size war" is provided, emphasizing consensus prior to changes to prevent divisiveness and network instability. The narrative advocates for careful planning and learning from past experiences to ensure Bitcoin's robustness, touching on the nuanced roles of miners and the importance of unity in the network's operation. The discourse is enriched by a [book on the block size war](https://www.amazon.com/Blocksize-War-Control-Bitcoins-Protocol/dp/B096CLR1SS/) for further insights.
The transformation within the Bitcoin ecosystem towards decentralization raises uncertainties, especially concerning "rough consensus." The socio-economic challenges of adapting to this shift due to coordination costs and review processes are discussed. The debates around miner-activated upgrades, the skepticism towards optional soft forks, and the need for novel consensus mechanisms underscore the reevaluation of change introduction and activation in a decentralized context.
Rusty Russell's blog post introduces a model for Bitcoin soft fork activation as "Devs propose. Miners activate. Users override," delineating the roles of each group in the activation process. This model, detailed in [A Model for Bitcoin Soft Fork Activation](http://rusty.ozlabs.org/2021/02/26/a-model-for-bitcoin-soph-fork-activation.html), promotes a balanced power distribution, encouraging broader consensus and dialogue on governance in the decentralized environment of cryptocurrency.
